Basta uno sguardo ai loro cuori per rendersene conto, dato che continuano a scintillare e a bruciare anche molto tempo dopo essere stati rimossi dal corpo del loro proprietario. I fabbri sanno da tempo come trasformare questi cuori in utili lampade.
Scarti dello scudo del gigante del fuoco

Gli scudi di una dreadnought di giganti del fuoco sono troppo grandi per essere impugnati o trasportati da qualsiasi avventuriero di dimensioni normali. I loro meccanismi interni, tuttavia, sono realizzati con maestria e possono essere forgiati solo dalla prestigiosa forza del gigante del fuoco e dalla sua affinità con la fiamma. Questi congegni possono essere portati da uno stagnino, che molto probabilmente accetterà volentieri l'opportunità di sperimentare un'attività artigianale così interessante.

table.name: Frost Giant Everlasting One
rows: Ciocca di capelli giganti di ghiaccio

Assomigliando alla brina del primo mattino, i capelli di un gigante di ghiaccio sono considerati una risorsa preziosa da cacciatori ed esploratori. I capelli di un gigante del gelo rimangono soprannaturalmente freddi nella maggior parte dei climi anche molto tempo dopo la morte del gigante. Imballare i prodotti deperibili in un sacchetto rivestito di peli di gigante del gelo è un buon metodo per conservarli quando non è disponibile nessun'altra opzione.

Come tutti i giganti, l'unghia del gigante del gelo è un componente fondamentale per preparare l'onnipresente {@item potion of giant strength|DMG}. Nonostante l'idea sbagliata degli avventurieri che credono che l'abbattimento di un gigante possa fornire loro pozioni per tutta la vita, è possibile preparare una sola pozione per gigante. Questo perché il processo alchemico utilizza l'unghia come focolaio di canalizzazione per evocare la forza di quel particolare gigante, rendendo così vano qualsiasi altro tentativo.

La lingua di un gigante del gelo è straordinariamente sensibile, per una creatura così feroce. Incapaci di sopportare temperature che per la maggior parte degli umanoidi potrebbero a malapena essere considerate "calde", queste lingue sono state adattate per una serie di strumenti, tra cui la borsa del freddo.

Un perenne è un gigante di ghiaccio che è stato toccato da Varpak. Divorando un troll inviato dal famelico dio, lo stomaco di un gigante del gelo cambia irrimediabilmente e porta segni simili a morsi, poiché Varpak divora tutto ciò che il gigante del gelo mangia. Questi segni possono essere estratti dallo stomaco di un perenne e usati per incantare le armi con una pericolosa benedizione.

table.name: Mouth of Grolantor
rows: Ciocca di capelli del gigante della collina

Simile alla boscaglia sulla cima di una collina arida, il pelo del gigante delle colline è considerato una risorsa preziosa per i lavoratori del cuoio. Il pelo del gigante delle colline, pur essendo sgradevole al tatto, è un ottimo materiale per le corde e persino i giganti delle colline stessi lo usano per cucire i loro vestiti.

Come tutti i giganti, l'unghia del gigante delle colline è un componente fondamentale per la preparazione dell'onnipresente {@item potion of giant strength|DMG}. Nonostante l'idea sbagliata degli avventurieri che credono che l'abbattimento di un gigante possa fornire loro pozioni per tutta la vita, è possibile preparare una sola pozione per gigante. Questo perché il processo alchemico utilizza l'unghia come focolaio di canalizzazione per evocare la forza di quel particolare gigante, rendendo così vano qualsiasi altro tentativo.

entries: Lo stomaco di un gigante delle colline è una cosa straordinaria, in grado di digerire e gestire praticamente tutto. Per questo motivo, è un punto di particolare interesse nel raro caso in cui qualcosa riesca a fargli fare indigestione. I giganti delle colline credono che si tratti di un presagio del loro dio Grolantor, mentre gli studiosi sostengono che sia solo un'influenza intestinale. In ogni caso, lo stomaco del gigante delle colline reagisce producendo enzimi speciali che tentano di curare il gigante, ma che una volta digeriti lo mandano in bestia. Sebbene possa essere pietosa per il gigante, questa bile può diventare particolarmente utile se si riesce a metterci le mani sopra, poiché i suoi usi nella magia sono molto potenti. {@b Requires {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI}.}

entries.name: Use:
entries: Quando si lancia l'incantesimo {@spell confusion}, si può usare questa fiala di bile al posto dei normali componenti materiali dell'incantesimo. Se lo fai, ogni volta che una creatura sotto l'effetto del tuo incantesimo {@spell confusion} tira un {@dice d10} per determinare il suo comportamento, puoi scegliere di farle ripetere il tiro di {@dice d10} e puoi scegliere tra i due risultati. L'uso della bile in questo modo non la consuma e può essere riutilizzata quante volte si vuole.

table.name: Stone Giant Dreamwalker
rows: Simile a una macchia di radica che ricopre un masso, il pelo di un gigante di pietra è considerato una risorsa preziosa per gli scalpellini. Incredibilmente ruvidi e setolosi, questi peli possono essere utilizzati per levigare la pietra. Ottenere una quantità considerevole dal gigante di pietra, solitamente privo di peli, può tuttavia rivelarsi una sfida in sé.

Come tutti i giganti, l'unghia del gigante di pietra è un componente fondamentale per la preparazione dell'onnipresente {@item potion of giant strength|DMG}. Nonostante l'idea sbagliata degli avventurieri che credono che l'abbattimento di un gigante possa fornire loro pozioni per tutta la vita, è possibile preparare una sola pozione per gigante. Questo perché il processo alchemico utilizza l'unghia come focolaio di canalizzazione per evocare la forza di quel particolare gigante, rendendo così vano qualsiasi altro tentativo.

I denti dei giganti di pietra sono più duri e più densi persino dei massi più antichi. I loro molari, in particolare, si sono rivelati particolarmente utili per gli scalpellini che desiderano emulare la leggendaria arte dei giganti di pietra. In effetti, si sa che alcuni giganti di pietra invecchiati regalano i loro denti sciolti ai piccoli abitanti a cui si sono affezionati, nella speranza che li usino per portare avanti la loro eredità.

Il cervello di un gigante di pietra sognatore non assomiglia affatto a un cervello. I segni di calcificazione estrema abbondano in tutto l'organo, facendolo assomigliare più a un grosso pezzo di pomice. È interessante notare che la calcificazione è più estrema nelle aree del cervello note per essere responsabili della visione, dell'identità e del processo decisionale. Per questo alcuni teorizzano che lo stato di "sognatore" dei giganti di pietra possa essere in realtà una forma di malattia piuttosto che un'esperienza quasi mistica.

table.name: Storm Giant Quintessent
rows: Il quintessente di un gigante delle tempeste non ha una forma fisica stabile e si disperde invece nell'atmosfera che lo circonda, vorticando come una vera e propria forza della natura. Detto questo, gran parte della loro essenza si può trovare distillata in un singolo frammento di tempo. A volte questo prende la forma di gocce di pioggia scintillanti, di una brezza che porta con sé un sussurro del nome del gigante o di un fiocco di neve con un disegno particolarmente suggestivo. Questo frammento porta con sé gran parte del potere del gigante della tempesta originale ed è quindi un buon sostituto dei suoi resti fisici quando viene utilizzato in attività alchemiche. {@b Requires {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI}.}
Acqua Quintessente del Gigante della Tempesta (fiala)

Un quintessente gigante della tempesta è in grado di trasformare parti della sua stessa tempesta in armi da usare in combattimento. Per farlo, deve imprimere all'atmosfera ambientale lo stesso senso di fisicità e stabilità che ha usato su se stesso per mantenere una forma gigante riconoscibile. Una volta che il quintessente è stato sconfitto, una parte di questo potere impartito rimane nelle sue armi disperse, che possono essere frettolosamente raccolte per essere utilizzate in seguito in potenti alchimie. {@b Requires {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI}.}

Anche se la sua forma si è dispersa nell'atmosfera circostante, lo spirito di un gigante della tempesta quintessente continua a imperversare più forte che mai. Se la sua forma fisica viene dissipata, il suo spirito fisicamente slegato può essere impresso su un pezzo di {@item spirit paper|HHHVI} che può essere poi trasferito in un potente mantello. {@b Requires {@item spirit paper|HHHVI}.}

table.name: Girallon
rows: Bianca come la neve, spessa, ma più morbida di quanto sembri. Per questo motivo, la pelliccia di girallon è stata riutilizzata come materiale per il parrucchino da chiunque possa permetterselo, e sicuramente è stata trovata in più di una parrucca aristocratica. Questo ha dato origine al termine dispregiativo della classe inferiore per i nobili fuori dal coro: "scalpo di girallone".
Ingiallita, dura e affilata, la zanna di Girallon è stata trasformata in qualsiasi cosa, dalle posate agli attrezzi agricoli, fino alle armi.
{@filter Any +1 melee piercing weapon|items|source=|type=melee weapon|category=specific variant|weapon damage type=p|bonus=weapon attack and damage rolls (+1)}

A causa della natura magica-artificiale di un girallon, le sue parti del corpo sono in grado di imprimere le loro proprietà a chiunque indossi un equipaggiamento fatto con esse. Ciò è particolarmente vero per i piedi, che possono essere trasformati in un paio di stivali che garantiscono a chi li indossa i piedi opponibili di un primate.

table.name: Flind
rows: I denti affilati e irregolari di uno gnoll. Non valgono molto se non come trofeo. Si consiglia ai raccoglitori di lavarli alla prima occasione, poiché portano con sé il fetore della bocca di uno gnoll anche dopo la rimozione.

Come omaggio al loro signore demoniaco, gli gnoll particolarmente zelanti si dipingono con il marchio del {@creature Yeenoghu|MTF} usando il sangue delle loro vittime. I marchi non hanno l'effetto desiderato di rendere lo gnoll invulnerabile, ma soprattutto sono dovuti all'incompetenza dello gnoll stesso. I marchi stessi possiedono in realtà un grado di magia che i demonologi apprezzano come materiale di ricerca e componente.

Un flind è uno gnoll che è stato particolarmente toccato dal principe demone {@creature Yeenoghu|MTF}. Se si incide il suo cuore, si scopre che non gocciola di sangue, ma di un pessimo odore che assomiglia e puzza come la bava di una iena rabbiosa.

table.name: Gnoll Flesh Gnawer
rows: I denti affilati e irregolari di uno gnoll. Non valgono molto se non come trofeo. Si consiglia ai raccoglitori di lavarli alla prima occasione, poiché portano con sé il fetore della bocca di uno gnoll anche dopo la rimozione.

table.name: Gnoll Hunter
rows: I denti affilati e irregolari di uno gnoll. Non valgono molto se non come trofeo. Si consiglia ai raccoglitori di lavarli alla prima occasione, poiché portano con sé il fetore della bocca di uno gnoll anche dopo la rimozione.

table.name: Gnoll Witherling
rows: Lo scheletro di uno gnoll trasformato in un Witherling è più o meno uguale a tutti gli altri. Tuttavia, l'esposizione prolungata agli elementi può far sì che si formi uno strato unico di polvere della consistenza (e dell'odore) di un formaggio molto stagionato. Sebbene questa polvere non sia apertamente magica, è molto utile per asciugare gli inchiostri mistici che i culti diabolici usano per scrivere i loro oscuri tomi e pergamene. Inutile dire che questo prodotto ha un mercato molto di nicchia.

I denti affilati e irregolari di uno gnoll. Non valgono molto se non come trofeo. Si consiglia ai raccoglitori di lavarli alla prima occasione, poiché portano con sé il fetore della bocca di uno gnoll anche dopo la rimozione.

table.name: Grung
rows: Purtroppo, il veleno di un grung viene neutralizzato poco dopo la raccolta ed è quindi di fatto inutile. La ghiandola velenifera, tuttavia, possiede ancora tracce di enzimi e sostanze chimiche che, se preparate a lungo, creano un leggero allucinogeno. Alcune tribù yuan-ti che vivono vicino alle tribù grung sono state trovate con vasi di argilla pieni di questa bevanda allucinogena, apparentemente per scopi cerimoniali.

table.name: Grung Elite Warrior
rows: Purtroppo, il veleno di un grung viene neutralizzato poco dopo la raccolta ed è quindi di fatto inutile. La ghiandola velenifera, tuttavia, possiede ancora tracce di enzimi e sostanze chimiche che, se preparate a lungo, creano un leggero allucinogeno. Alcune tribù yuan-ti che vivono vicino alle tribù grung sono state trovate con vasi di argilla pieni di questa bevanda allucinogena, apparentemente per scopi cerimoniali.

Nelle giungle occupate dai grung, l'eco del loro caratteristico chirr può essere udito ovunque si vada. Il chirr è più pericoloso quando viene emesso dai loro guerrieri d'élite, caratterizzati da una colorazione arancione o dorata. Questi grung possiedono una serie di membrane conservate in una sacca sotto il mento che, quando vengono gorgheggiate in modo appropriato, creano una melodia più ipnotica che può ottundere i sensi degli ignari. Alcuni bardi più abili hanno iniziato a usare questi sacchi in strumenti musicali che possono creare alcuni degli stessi toni ipnotici e ipnotici.

table.name: Grung Wildling
rows: Purtroppo, il veleno di un grung viene neutralizzato poco dopo la raccolta ed è quindi di fatto inutile. La ghiandola velenifera, tuttavia, possiede ancora tracce di enzimi e sostanze chimiche che, se preparate a lungo, creano un leggero allucinogeno. Alcune tribù yuan-ti che vivono vicino alle tribù grung sono state trovate con vasi di argilla pieni di questa bevanda allucinogena, apparentemente per scopi cerimoniali.

table.name: Grung Trinket Table
rows: {@dice 1d4} giorni di {@item rations (1 day)|PHB|rations} (radici e creature della palude)
1 serie di carcasse di creature della palude
{@dice 1d4} legami fatti con fibre di piante palustri
1 buccia di succo di cimice fermentato

table.name: Guard Drake
rows: Sangue di Drake della Guardia (3 fiale)

Il sangue di un drago della guardia assomiglia molto a quello di un drago vero, ma la sua lucentezza è notevolmente attenuata ed è molto più viscoso del famoso sangue di drago che scorre liberamente. Sebbene contenga molto meno potenziale magico, il sangue di drago della guardia sembra avere un odore abbastanza simile a quello del sangue di drago normale da confondere l'olfatto di un drago, dando così origine al suo utilizzo in alcune esche/repellenti per draghi.
Scaglie di Drake della Guardia (astuccio piccolo)

Poiché un drago della guardia è formato dalle scaglie di un drago, non c'è da stupirsi che le sue scaglie assomiglino a quelle dei suoi progenitori. Tuttavia, sono di qualità molto inferiore e ricordano più le scaglie lisce di un serpente che le pesanti placche di un vero drago. Sebbene siano inutili per la creazione di draghi da guardia o per la realizzazione di armature, possono essere utilizzate per confezionare abiti eleganti nelle suggestive tonalità dei voli cromatici dei draghi.

entries: Il cuore di un drago guardiano è uno degli unici organi veramente magici del suo corpo, poiché condivide un legame innato con il drago che lo ha creato. Con un po' di modifiche magiche, può essere usato per seguire i draghi ovunque vada.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Se si lancia l'incantesimo {@spell locate creature} su questo cuore una volta al giorno per 10 giorni consecutivi, esso diventa permanentemente incantato e reagisce alla presenza di draghi dello stesso colore del drago guardiano da cui è stato preso il cuore. Mentre è incantato in questo modo, il cuore inizierà a battere quando si trova entro 1.000 piedi da quel colore di drago, e il cuore batterà sempre più velocemente quanto più vicino è il drago.

table.name: Annis Hag
rows: I capelli di una strega annis si ammucchiano come muschio su un masso rovinato dalle intemperie. Impregnati di tracce della magia corruttrice della megera, sembra quasi che crescano e si attacchino alla mano quando li si stringe.

Assolutamente puzzolente del fetore che permeava l'intero essere della megera, bere questo sangue ha il potenziale di infettare una creatura con {@disease crone's disease|HHHVI}. Va inoltre notato che, sebbene il sangue abbia un odore e un sapore fetido come quello che sembra, l'alcol ha un effetto neutralizzante su entrambe le proprietà. Ciò che qualcuno fa con queste informazioni è del tutto fuori dal controllo di chi scrive.

Una megera annis tende ad avere un certo numero di denti di ferro che ha conficcato nelle gengive e fuso magicamente con il proprio cranio. Questo teschio possiede quindi un forte potere magico, simile a quello dei gettoni di ferro che consegna ai bambini ingenui, ed è quindi in grado di essere sfruttato da chi ha conoscenze di artificeria.

entries: Non va confuso con il famigerato amuleto "occhio di strega" regalato dalle megere alle loro serve, ma le due cose sono strettamente collegate. Nonostante sia stato reciso dalla sua cavità, questo occhio sembra ancora brillare come in vita.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Come azione potete {@condition concentration|PHB|concentrate} sul bulbo oculare della megera mentre è nella vostra mano. Nel farlo, si può utilizzare l'occhio della megera nello stesso modo in cui l'avrebbe utilizzato in vita. Se l'occhio della megera viene distrutto mentre ci si concentra su di esso, si subiscono {@damage 3d10} danni psichici e si subisce {@condition blinded} per 24 ore.

table.name: Bheur Hag
rows: Nonostante assomiglino alla brina che cresce sulle ragnatele, i capelli di una bheur hag sono sorprendentemente morbidi e flessibili. Possedendo tracce dell'antica magia del gelo della megera, questi capelli sono stati trasformati in corde per varie invenzioni, impartendo il loro potere invernale ovunque vengano utilizzati.

Assolutamente puzzolente del fetore che permeava l'intero essere della megera, bere questo sangue ha il potenziale di infettare una creatura con {@disease crone's disease|HHHVI}. Va inoltre notato che, sebbene il sangue abbia un odore e un sapore fetido come quello che sembra, l'alcol ha un effetto neutralizzante su entrambe le proprietà. Ciò che qualcuno fa con queste informazioni è del tutto fuori dal controllo di chi scrive.

Una volta rimosso dalla sua carne tesa e congelata, il cranio di una megera bheur sfoggia un costante ghigno rictus. Fissa chiunque lo guardi, deridendolo con pensieri di ansia e disperazione, indipendentemente dalla sua situazione attuale. È pericoloso usarlo per il crafting, ma se ben fatto, può creare un oggetto che trasuda magia oscura e la lentezza dell'inverno.

entries: Non va confuso con il famigerato amuleto "occhio di strega" regalato dalle megere alle loro serve, ma le due cose sono strettamente collegate. Nonostante sia stato reciso dalla sua cavità, questo occhio sembra ancora brillare come in vita.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Come azione potete {@condition concentration|PHB|concentrate} sul bulbo oculare della megera mentre è nella vostra mano. Nel farlo, si può utilizzare l'occhio della megera nello stesso modo in cui l'avrebbe utilizzato in vita. Se l'occhio della megera viene distrutto mentre ci si concentra su di esso, si subiscono {@damage 3d10} danni psichici e si subisce {@condition blinded} per 24 ore.

table.name: Hobgoblin Devastator
rows: Il corpo di un hobgoblin ha poca utilità pratica per i raccoglitori. Tuttavia, la maggior parte delle città pagherà piccole taglie per le orecchie di hobgoblin.

Quando un hobgoblin cresce in esperienza e prestigio, si fa crescere i capelli in trecce che vengono tagliate solo se perde una battaglia. Queste trecce hanno un certo valore per i collezionisti e per gli uffici taglie come prova dell'abbattimento di una minaccia hobgoblin degna di nota.

table.name: Hobgoblin Iron Shadow
rows: Il corpo di un hobgoblin ha poca utilità pratica per i raccoglitori. Tuttavia, la maggior parte delle città pagherà piccole taglie per le orecchie di hobgoblin.

Quando un hobgoblin cresce in esperienza e prestigio, si fa crescere i capelli in trecce che vengono tagliate solo se perde una battaglia. Queste trecce hanno un certo valore per i collezionisti e per gli uffici taglie come prova dell'abbattimento di una minaccia hobgoblin degna di nota.

table.name: Hobgoblin Trinket Table
rows: 1 piccola quantità {@item pouch|PHB} di erbe anestetiche

table.name: Ki-Rin
rows: Il sangue dorato e scintillante di un ki-rin scorre come il miele fresco. Ovunque il sangue fuoriesca, la vita vegetale è sicuramente fiorente, il che spesso fa sì che i luoghi di morte dei ki-rin diventino magnifici giardini in loro onore. Il sangue del ki-rin, che conferisce vigore, si mescola facilmente alle pozioni ed è quindi un reagente prezioso per tutti i tipi di pozioni ricostituenti.

entries: Brillante come l'oro filato, ma più morbida della seta, la pelliccia di ki-rin è ambita in lungo e in largo per la filatura di abiti degni solo di re e imperatori. Oltre all'uso in sartoria, la magia riparatrice insita nel ki-rin rende la sua pelliccia perfetta per essere usata come benda, e la pelliccia di ki-rin si trova di serie nei kit di guarigione dei palazzi imperiali.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Si può scegliere di usare un dardo di pelliccia di ki-rin come benda ogni volta che si tira un dado ferita per recuperare punti ferita durante un riposo breve. In questo caso, si rinuncia al tiro e si ottiene il massimo valore possibile da quel dado. Una benda di pelliccia di ki-rin usata una volta non può essere usata di nuovo finché non è stata immersa in acqua pulita per almeno 8 ore.

rows: Dorate come il sole del mattino, le scaglie di un ki-rin sono intrinsecamente magiche e proteggono chi le indossa con una forza magica. Per essere utili, le squame devono essere trattate come la pelle di un rettile e conciate in modo adeguato, ma una volta completate costituiscono un'armatura celestiale.

Gli zoccoli color rame di un ki-rin sono molto più duri del metallo a cui assomigliano. Una volta rinforzati e fissati a una robusta impugnatura, sono in grado di colpire il male anche dopo la morte del loro proprietario.
{@filter Any +2 melee bludgeoning weapon|items|source=|type=melee weapon|category=specific variant|weapon damage type=b|bonus=weapon attack and damage rolls (+2)}

La saggezza dei ki-rin è leggendaria e i loro cuori sono in grado di individuare il male e la menzogna ogni volta che sono in loro presenza. Quando la loro potente magia viene incorporata in un set di scaglie dorate, sono in grado di continuare a giudicare i malvagi anche dopo la morte.

Il corno di un ki-rin emana una debole tonalità dorata anche dopo essere stato tolto al suo proprietario originale. Nonostante assomigli superficialmente a un normale corno, il corno di un ki-rin è formato da una speciale cheratina che incanala particolarmente bene le energie magiche ed è quindi adatto alla creazione di bacchette, bastoni e aste magiche.

table.name: Kobold Dragonshield
rows: Come un coccodrillo, i kobold crescono e perdono continuamente denti nel corso della loro vita. Per questo motivo, le loro mascelle tendono a essere rivestite da file affilate di bianchi perlacei freschi. I Kobold li usano come strumenti e non c'è motivo per cui le altre razze dovrebbero rifiutarsi di fare lo stesso se si presentasse l'occasione.
Cuore di scudo di drago Kobold

entries: Un kobold che si fregia del titolo di scudo del drago è un kobold che è stato cresciuto da un patrono draconico fino a raggiungere le vette del potenziale kobold (in realtà non è ancora un gran risultato). I loro cuori presentano lievi mutazioni che aggiungono ulteriore adrenalina nei momenti di stress, consentendo loro di andare avanti quando altri kobold vacillerebbero (anche in questo caso, non si tratta di un risultato così impressionante).

entries.name: Use:
entries: Come azione si può mangiare questo cuore o darlo in pasto a un alleato consenziente. Se il mangiatore è affetto da un effetto {@condition frightened} o {@condition paralyzed|PHB|paralysis} che consentirebbe un tiro salvezza per porvi fine, può tentare immediatamente il tiro salvezza con vantaggio.

table.name: Kobold Inventor
rows: Come un coccodrillo, i kobold crescono e perdono continuamente denti nel corso della loro vita. Per questo motivo, le loro mascelle tendono a essere rivestite da file affilate di bianchi perlacei freschi. I Kobold li usano come strumenti e non c'è motivo per cui le altre razze dovrebbero rifiutarsi di fare lo stesso se si presentasse l'occasione.

table.name: Kobold Scale Sorcerer
rows: Come un coccodrillo, i kobold crescono e perdono continuamente denti nel corso della loro vita. Per questo motivo, le loro mascelle tendono a essere rivestite da file affilate di bianchi perlacei freschi. I Kobold li usano come strumenti e non c'è motivo per cui le altre razze dovrebbero rifiutarsi di fare lo stesso se si presentasse l'occasione.

table.name: Kobold Trinket Table
rows: 1 mantello che ricorda le ali di un drago
{@dice 1d4} pezzi di guscio d'uovo di drago

table.name: Korred

entries: Lo zoccolo di un korred è sensibile alla terra come le orecchie di un pipistrello al suono. Piccole sacche d'aria all'interno di questi zoccoli permettono loro di vibrare al minimo tremore del terreno e li rendono sorprendentemente leggeri. I Duergar sono stati trovati a usare questi zoccoli come strumenti per la loro speleologia, ma nulla impedisce al resto di noi di fare lo stesso se mai dovessimo trovarci in possesso di uno di essi.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Tenendo questo oggetto contro la pietra o il terreno, si guadagna un {@sense tremorsense|MM} fino a una portata di 9 metri.

I capelli dei korred sono uno dei materiali più unici del Multiverso, in grado di trasformarsi in qualsiasi materiale venga utilizzato per tagliarli. Se si vuole conservare il capello nel suo stato versatile, c'è una soluzione relativamente macabra: prendere l'intero cuoio capelluto del korred. In questo caso, si consiglia di intrecciare i capelli prima di conservarli, poiché alla morte del korred diventano piuttosto fragili e soggetti a danni.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Questo scalpo contiene 10 trecce di 1 piede di lunghezza ciascuna. Quando vengono tagliate, queste trecce si trasformano in modo permanente in qualsiasi materiale sia stato usato per tagliarle. Una volta rimossi tutti i capelli da questo cuoio capelluto, esso diventa inutile.

rows: Grigia come la pietra e ruvida come il granito, la pelle del korred non è piacevole da toccare. Tuttavia, possiede molte proprietà magiche che conferiscono al korred la famosa capacità di nuotare nella pietra. Se usata come rivestimento interno di un'armatura, queste proprietà possono essere trasferite a chi la indossa (basta assicurarsi di indossare una maglia intima comoda).

table.name: Leucrotta
rows: La bile di Leucrotta è diversa da quella di qualsiasi altra creatura mortale ed è più simile a quella di un demone. Capace di digerire l'indigeribile, una volta diluita e mescolata con agenti neutralizzanti, la bile è un'utile pozione per gli avventurieri survivalisti.

La pelle di una Leucrotta è odiosa e oleosa come una coperta di un vagabondo. Persino i pellettieri che hanno sviluppato una resistenza all'orrido fetore della conceria non possono sopportare di stare vicino a una Leucrotta. Tuttavia, con un trattamento approfondito e l'uso strategico di profumi, una pelle di Leucrotta è un'ottima pelle da pioggia grazie ai suoi oli naturali.

Rather than individual teeth, a Leucrotta simply has a bony ridge that runs around the circumference of its mouth. This mouth ridge is said to be as strong as adamantium, and indeed has been shown to be strong enough to tear through steel and rock alike.

table.name: Meenlock
rows: The meenlock claw is known for its ability to paralyze the creatures that it strikes. Unfortunately, it loses much of its magical potency upon its death and is capable of inflicting nothing more than a slight numbing sensation. Ironically, these claws have been repurposed by Feywild inhabitants as herding rods to calm over-agitated livestock.

entries: Resembling an overgrown ant head, a meenlock's head is truly something to behold. Other than its use as a wonderful wall ornament, it can be hollowed out and used as a helmet with limited forms of some of the meenlock's abilities.

entries.name: Use:
entries: When you make a Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check while holding this head, you may choose to do so at advantage. Once this ability has been used 5 times, the head loses all magic and becomes worthless.

rows: A meenlock is a being born out of emotion, and this emotion can be harvested with a quick application of {@item spirit paper|HHHVI}. Hags in particular are fond of harvesting meenlocks for their spirits in order to craft insidious curses. {@b Requires {@item spirit paper|HHHVI}.}

table.name: Alhoon
rows: Due to a lack of mucus, an alhoon's skin is noticeably pale and flakey and can literally crumble once the alhoon has died. Completely useless for any kind of leatherworking, crushing the skin into a dust and inhaling it has been known to induce a psychosis that makes one believe they have died (despite their breathing and walking around providing evidence to the contrary). For some strange reason, some people find this experience to be quite cathartic, causing alhoon dust to be offered in the more exotic entertainment dens.

Dry and brittle, an alhoon's tentacles have lost much of the strength and dexterity of a living illithid's. While they have been rendered useless for the purposes of weapon crafting, these tentacles make for a potent magical ink once powdered and mixed with enchanted chalks.

As part of an illithid's descent into becoming an alhoon, they must forsake their colony and elder brain, an emotionally painful act even for the usually indifferent illithids. To recover from this self-inflicted wound, alhoons erect barriers around their hearts, both figuratively and literally. With their burgeoning understanding of magic, alhoons cast spells that numb their hearts and prevent them from yearning for a colony they may never return to. This magic remains in their hearts even after their death and yields great benefits when artificing.

The brain of an alhoon is substantially different to that of a regular illithid. Having severed their connection to the elder brain, the lobes responsible for communication and community are noticeably atrophied, whereas the sections related to curiosity and learning have grown. When used in artificing, the result is substantially different to using a regular illithid's, and instead takes inspiration from the alhoon's nefarious periapt of mind trapping.

table.name: Elder Brain

entries: The fluids secreted by an elder brain resemble that of the fluids excreted by a regular humanoid's, but are in fact more akin to that of an illithid's mucus secretion. This fluid is a rich miasma of enzymes and grey matter that when imbibed, has strong perception altering effects for anyone that is not an illithid.

entries.name: Use:
entries: As an action you may drink a vial of this brain fluid. If you do so, for the next 1 hour you automatically succeed on detecting the nature of illusions upon seeing them. At the end of the hour, you automatically suffer one level of {@condition exhaustion} as your brain resets its sensory intake methods.

rows: Although considerably longer than an illithid's, an elder brain's tentacle possesses many of the same anatomical features. When crafted into a whip, they are capable of scouring both the flesh and the mind.

The connective tissue between the many folds and neurons of an elder brain, harvesting this material intact requires an extremely steady hand and extensive medical knowledge. It is however an extremely useful crafting material as it lends itself well for making items that take advantage of its original purpose as a biological method of transmitting information.

The elder brain's telepathic gland is a roughly apple sized bulb located on its temporal lobe. Although it is relatively small, the telepathic gland has a huge reach and is responsible for many of the elder brain's psionic abilities. Harvesting it intact is difficult, but it can serve as the basis for powerful magical items.

The thalamus of an elder brain is much like a regular humanoid's and contributes to their prestigious memory. It takes a very skilled artificer to transform it into a magical item, but when done properly, it allows a user to tap into the limitless knowledge of the elder brain.

table.name: Ulitharid
rows: The mucus secreted by a well fed mind flayer has a slightly sticky texture and smells roughly of weak formaldahyde. Filled with the thoughts and emotions of the mind flayer's meals, this mucus can undergo an alchemical process to turn into an intoxicating draught known as: Whisper. When consumed, the drinker experiences a rush of euphoria as dozens of minds recount lost knowledge and memories in a cascade of mental whispers. While unpleasant, this drink is considered a high honour in many Underdark societies.

The mouth tentacle of the mind flayer is renowned for affecting more than the physical on every lash. It retains this property beyond the death of its owner, and Underdark interrogators are rumored to use whips made of these tentacles in their work.
A mind flayer heart is a dark organ, filled with vile humours and thin ichors. When transformed into an amulet, it can grant many of the psionic abilities of an illithid, but at a terrible price.

The brain of an ulitharid is larger and denser than that of a regular illithid. Within an ulitharid brain is the potential to grow into a formidable elder brain, much like how a caterpillar possesses the potential to grow into a butterfly (although in a much less pleasant way). As part of this, an ulitharid brain boats an engorged cerebrum and communication centers, which bolsters its telepathic abilities and enables it to serve as a portable psionic hub for its colony.

table.name: Mindwitness
rows: A mindwitness' tentacles greatly resembles that of a mind flayer's in terms of both anatomy and function. Able to stun its prey like a mind flayer's they also make great whips, but their inferior strength means that they need a bit more craftwork to become usable.

The eye stalks of a mindwitness are irrevocably changed by the corruption of an elder brain to favor psionic abilities. That said, they are still useful for crafting magical wands, and depending on what your desired effect is, could be considered even better than a normal beholder's. If a player harvests an eye stalk, roll {@dice 1d6}. The type of eye stalk they receive corresponds to the number rolled, as described in the mindwitness' statblock.

The main eye of a mindwitness is a pitiful thing to behold (pardon the pun). Due to the beholder's mutation by the elder brain, its main eye has been repurposed into an extension of its brain, losing its infamous anti-magic abilities in the process. Instead, it gains the ability to project thoughts telepathically into those it can see (thus the name), becoming little more than a glorified mail carrier for an elder brain's plans. By combining this eye with a magically enhanced diffraction lens, it is possible to create an item capable of broadcasting one's thoughts en masse (which is a great tool to have when walking out of a poorly written theatre performance).

table.name: Morkoth

entries: A pearly-white substance found in distilled morkoth blood, this humor is believed to be derived from the celestial substance that first birthed this bizarre species. The celestial substance was believed to be some sort of solidified healing magic, lost in the chaotic spaces of the Astral Plane. As such, it makes for a fantastic base for particularly powerful healing potions or to bolster one's healing magic.

entries.name: Use:
entries: When you cast a spell that would result in a creature recovering hit points without doing damage, you may expend 1 or more vials of morkoth humor as an additional material component. If you do so, you skip rolling a certain amount of dice to determine the amount of hit points recovered, and instead gain the maximum value of that dice roll. The amount of dice skipped is equal to the amount of vials of morkoth humor you expended.

rows: Those that have met a morkoth can attest to their strangely enchanting eyes that lure in unwary adventurers to their doom. It is thought by some that the salty dog tale of "lure lights" that cause sailors to throw themselves into the ocean are actually morkoths trying to add a few creatures to its collection.

Much like many cephalopods, a morkoth's tentacles is more than a simple appendage: it contains numerous nerve endings and neurons that allows it to act as an extension of the morkoth's brain. As such, morkoths can display an uncanny amount of control over their limbs, as well as gain much more sensory information from them than you and I can using our hands and fingers. These traits can be passed off onto a magical whip that almost moves independently in a wielder's hands.

A morkoth's gladius is a long piece of cartilage that runs through the entirety of its main body and is often thought of as the "spine" of a morkoth. Incredibly hardy, the gladius is responsible for the remarkable spell reflection ability possessed by the morkoth, and can be transformed into a magical kite shield with similar properties.

entries: Most likely due to their harsh natural selection that weeds out the weak-willed, neogi are naturally resistant to any form of emotional manipulation. Biologically, this comes in the form of an enlarged amygdala that gives the neogi a better "fight or flight" response than most humanoids and keeps them grounded in reality.

entries.name: Use:
entries: You may spend your action to eat the amygdala. If you do so, for the next hour you gain advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}, and magic can't put you to sleep.

A neogi is deadly even as soon as it is born; it has to be in order to kill all of its siblings and survive its first day of existence. As part of this, a hatchling comes into the world with its poison glands fully formed and productive. Funnily enough, this sometimes results in entire egg clutches dying as the victor of the hatching melee succumbs to the poison of their defeated broodmates.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Can be used to coat up to 5 pieces of slashing or piercing ammunition or one slashing or piercing weapon. Applying the poison takes 1 minute. For the next minute, any creature successfully hit must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 2d6} poison damage and become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. A target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

table.name: Neogi

entries: Most likely due to their harsh natural selection that weeds out the weak-willed, neogi are naturally resistant to any form of emotional manipulation. Biologically, this comes in the form of an enlarged amygdala that gives the neogi a better "fight or flight" response than most humanoids and keeps them grounded in reality.

entries.name: Use:
entries: You may spend your action to eat the amygdala. If you do so, for the next hour you gain advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}, and magic can't put you to sleep.

A neogi is deadly even as soon as it is born; it has to be in order to kill all of its siblings and survive its first day of existence. As part of this, a hatchling comes into the world with its poison glands fully formed and productive. Funnily enough, this sometimes results in entire egg clutches dying as the victor of the hatching melee succumbs to the poison of their defeated broodmates.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Can be used to coat up to 5 pieces of slashing or piercing ammunition or one slashing or piercing weapon. Applying the poison takes 1 minute. For the next minute, any creature successfully hit must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 2d6} poison damage and become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. A target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

rows: Neogi are known for their ability to enslave just about any creature it meets with a single glare, usually an umber hulk that it chooses to serve as its muscle. There is currently some conjecture among scholars that the umber hulk's infamous hypnotizing gaze and the neogi's enslavement glare are related in some way due to their constant exposure to each other, but there is little solid evidence to support this. Unfortunately the last scholar that went out of their way to find some never returned from their expedition.

table.name: Neogi Master

entries: Most likely due to their harsh natural selection that weeds out the weak-willed, neogi are naturally resistant to any form of emotional manipulation. Biologically, this comes in the form of an enlarged amygdala that gives the neogi a better "fight or flight" response than most humanoids and keeps them grounded in reality.

entries.name: Use:
entries: You may spend your action to eat the amygdala. If you do so, for the next hour you gain advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}, and magic can't put you to sleep.

A neogi is deadly even as soon as it is born; it has to be in order to kill all of its siblings and survive its first day of existence. As part of this, a hatchling comes into the world with its poison glands fully formed and productive. Funnily enough, this sometimes results in entire egg clutches dying as the victor of the hatching melee succumbs to the poison of their defeated broodmates.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Can be used to coat up to 5 pieces of slashing or piercing ammunition or one slashing or piercing weapon. Applying the poison takes 1 minute. For the next minute, any creature successfully hit must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 2d6} poison damage and become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. A target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

rows: Neogi are known for their ability to enslave just about any creature it meets with a single glare, usually an umber hulk that it chooses to serve as its muscle. There is currently some conjecture among scholars that the umber hulk's infamous hypnotizing gaze and the neogi's enslavement glare are related in some way due to their constant exposure to each other, but there is little solid evidence to support this. Unfortunately the last scholar that went out of their way to find some never returned from their expedition.

table.name: Neothelid
rows: A neothelid tentacle is a bizarre mockery of that of an illithid's. Although similar in many ways, they possess a duct that allows digestive enzymes to be passed out and onto enemies. This duct is of course useless once the tentacle has been removed from the neothelid's stomach, but the tentacle itself still serves as a good weapon base.

entries: The highly acidic contents of a neothelid's digestive tract are capable of melting through metal and flesh alike. Strangely enough however, it is completely unreactive when it comes into contact with brain matter. While this does allow the neothelid to consume their prey's brains intact, it does beg the question of how they actually end up digesting them once they've been swallowed.

entries.name: Use:
entries: As an action you may throw this sack at a point you can see within 20 feet of you, bursting on impact. All creatures within 5 feet of that point must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 10d6} acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

A neothelid's brain is pitiful in many ways. While it once held the potential for vast intelligence, it has become extremely limited due to its unnatural growth. Its psionic abilities however are still extremely powerful and are unchecked by any semblance of reason or strategy from the creature. In many ways, the neothelid is simply a tortured creature, given power it cannot control and perhaps does not even want. When used by an experienced spellcaster however, this power can be given direction and wielded with much greater purpose.

entries.name: Use:
entries: When you cast the {@spell confusion} spell, you may use this brain instead of the spell's usual material component. If you do so, instead of rolling {@dice 1d10} at the start of an affected creature's turn to determine their behavior, you may choose the result instead.

rows: Neothelid skin is notoriously difficult to harvest, sloughing off and melting quickly upon their deaths due to the reaction of their spilled digestive enzymes with their body mucus. If you do manage to harvest some however, their skin has natural protections against both magic and psionics, and has been adapted into wondrous armors and protective gear.

As a tadpole, a neothelid would have possessed a hook on the end of its tail to embed itself into the brain of its unlucky host. As a neothelid of course, it no longer needs to do this, and its vestigial hook has grown little in comparison to the rest of its body. Still, the hook possesses some magical ability and when turned into a weapon and applied properly, can be just as debilitating as it once would have been when used on a hapless victim.

table.name: Nilbog
rows: Goblins neither possess much of value, nor are made of anything of value. Goblin ears are perhaps the only thing worth carving off of an average goblin, if only because dogs enjoy snacking on them the same way they enjoy pig ears.

Even though a nilbog spirit abandons its physical host upon its defeat, it leaves its mark permanently in the form of a rictus grin on its old mouth. Mounting this macabre body part on a base of power can create an amusing novelty wand.

entries: A nilbog's spirit is almost impossible to pin down for even the most skilled occultists. The most one can hope to do is catch an echo of it using a ream of spirit paper. This echo is almost as illusive and slippery as the real spirit, and dissipates too easily to be used for crafting, making it a strictly single use item.

entries.name: Use:
entries: If you cast the {@spell sanctuary} spell, you may expend this item as a material component instead of the usual material component. If you do so, the first time the creature protected by your {@spell sanctuary} spell receives damage from another creature, they may spend their reaction to reduce that damage to 0 and recover {@dice 1d6} hit points instead.

table.name: Orc Blade of Ilneval

entries: The gift of fertility that was granted to the orcs by their deity, {@deity Luthic|Orc|VGM}, also gave their other fluids full compatibility with other humanoids. As such, drinking the blood of an orc can temporarily grant other humanoids some of the legendary ferocity of the orcs.

entries.name: Use:
entries: When you drink this vial of blood, you feel more aggressive for the next 10 minutes. During this time, you may spend your bonus action to move up to your speed toward a hostile creature you can see. After the 10 minutes have passed, you must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or suffer one point of {@condition exhaustion}.

A heart touched by the orc god {@deity Ilneval|Orc|VGM} beats noticeably faster than a regular orc heart, sometimes even still beating after being removed from its original owner's chest. It's almost as if it is still trying to fight beyond death.

entries.name: Use:
entries: You may spend your action to eat this heart. If you do so, for the next hour you gain the ability to spend your action to allow up to three allies within 120 feet of you that can hear you to use their reactions to make one weapon attack each. This benefit cannot be taken by any character with elvish ancestry.

rows: Ritual scarring is common among blades of {@deity Ilneval|Orc|VGM}, both as a means of proving one's devotion and of proving one's strength. While many may find them horrifying to look at, there do exist collectors that appreciate the unique patterns that a blade of {@deity Ilneval|Orc|VGM} will make in their skin, paying a premium for experienced blades that have also had the most time and practice to expand their marks.

entries: The gift of fertility that was granted to the orcs by their deity, {@deity Luthic|Orc|VGM}, also gave their other fluids full compatibility with other humanoids. As such, drinking the blood of an orc can temporarily grant other humanoids some of the legendary ferocity of the orcs.

entries.name: Use:
entries: When you drink this vial of blood, you feel more aggressive for the next 10 minutes. During this time, you may spend your bonus action to move up to your speed toward a hostile creature you can see. After the 10 minutes have passed, you must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or suffer one point of {@condition exhaustion}.

A heart touched by the orc god {@deity Luthic|Orc|VGM} is noticeably thicker and redder than a normal heart, perhaps symbolic of the love that orcish parents do show for their children (or it is reflective of the increased blood flow and strength that these orcs have that allow them to use their own claws in place of weapons).

entries.name: Use:
entries: You may spend your action to eat this heart. If you do so, for the next hour, whenever you cast a spell that restores hit points to a creature other than you, that creature may also spend their reaction to move up to their speed toward a hostile creature they can see. This benefit cannot be taken by any character with elvish ancestry.

The gift of fertility that was granted to the orcs by their deity, {@deity Luthic|Orc|VGM}, also gave their other fluids full compatibility with other humanoids. As such, drinking the blood of an orc can temporarily grant other humanoids some of the legendary ferocity of the orcs.

entries.name: Use:
entries: When you drink this vial of blood, you feel more aggressive for the next 10 minutes. During this time, you may spend your bonus action to move up to your speed toward a hostile creature you can see. After the 10 minutes have passed, you must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or suffer one point of {@condition exhaustion}.
A heart touched by the orc god {@deity Yurtrus|Orc|VGM} is horribly diseased and ridden with pustules. It is extremely unpalatable to consume, but to be honest, so should all other orc hearts.

entries.name: Use:
entries: You may spend your action to eat this heart. If you do so, for the next hour, any spell you cast does not require a verbal component. This benefit cannot be taken by any character with elvish ancestry.

table.name: Orc Nurtured One of Yurtrus
rows: The rotting pus and viscera of a nurtured one of {@deity Yurtrus|Orc|VGM} is absolutely packed with disease and plague. Luckily for most of us however, the disease cannot live long once exposed to the elements, and stops being a vector very soon after the death of its carrier. On the other hand, alchemists that have an interest in spreading maladies may make use of {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI|enchanted vials} to gather this ichor and brew it into a most insidious poison. {@b Requires {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI}.}

entries: The gift of fertility that was granted to the orcs by their deity, {@deity Luthic|Orc|VGM}, also gave their other fluids full compatibility with other humanoids. As such, drinking the blood of an orc can temporarily grant other humanoids some of the legendary ferocity of the orcs.

entries.name: Use:
entries: When you drink this vial of blood, you feel more aggressive for the next 10 minutes. During this time, you may spend your bonus action to move up to your speed toward a hostile creature you can see. After the 10 minutes have passed, you must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or suffer one point of {@condition exhaustion}.
A heart touched by {@deity Shargaas|Orc|VGM} is darker in color than a normal heart, as if permanently bathed in shadows.

entries.name: Use:
entries: You may spend your action to eat this heart. If you do so, for the next hour, magical darkness does not impede your vision any more than regular darkness would. This benefit cannot be taken by any character with elvish ancestry.

table.name: Tanarukk

entries: The gift of fertility that was granted to the orcs by their deity, {@deity Luthic|Orc|VGM}, also gave their other fluids full compatibility with other humanoids. As such, drinking the blood of an orc can temporarily grant other humanoids some of the legendary ferocity of the orcs.

entries.name: Use:
entries: When you drink this vial of blood, you feel more aggressive for the next 10 minutes. During this time, you may spend your bonus action to move up to your speed toward a hostile creature you can see. After the 10 minutes have passed, you must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or suffer one point of {@condition exhaustion}.

rows: Made of the same ivory that forms an orc's deadly tusk, a tanarukk's horn makes a formidable and intimidating weapon.
{@filter Any +1 melee piercing weapon|items|source=|type=melee weapon|category=specific variant|weapon damage type=p|bonus=weapon attack and damage rolls (+1)}

entries: A tanarukk's aggression is legendary among even the notoriously angry orcish race. Part of this is due to its oversized adrenal glands that constantly cause the tanarukk to be in a fight or flight mode (and more often than not, choosing fight).

entries.name: Use:
entries: You may spend your action to eat this gland. If you do so, for the next hour, whenever you are hit by a melee attack within range, you may spend your reaction to make one melee weapon attack with advantage against the attacker. After the hour, you must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or suffer one point of {@condition exhaustion}.

table.name: Orc Trinket Table
rows: {@dice 1d6} lumps of fuel (dried manure and hay)

table.name: Quickling

entries: Quickling blood remains in motion even after it is drained from its body. Thinner than the blood of any other mortal creature, a quickling's blood is loaded with adrenaline and other enzymes that when drunk by a humanoid, slows their perception of time and gives them enhanced reflexes. The crash after the effect has worn off can be rather harsh however.

entries.name: Use:
entries: You may spend your action to drink this blood. If you do so, you gain an extra reaction per round on top of your usual amount. This benefit lasts for 1 hour, after which you suffer one level of {@condition exhaustion}.

rows: The hide of a quickling is extraordinarily smooth, allowing it to reduce wind resistance as much as physically possible. While it may seem barbaric, their hide makes a wonderful base for the ubiquitous boots of speed.

table.name: Redcap
rows: It is difficult to tell where a redcap's feet end and where their boots begin. Since they never take them off (and are even born wearing them), their feet quite often fuse into the boots themselves. While this is admittedly quite distasteful to look at, it does impart an essence of fey magic into metal form (something that is usually impossible due to the incompatibility between fey creatures and iron).

Regularly soaked in the fresh blood of its victims, the eponymous cap of the redcap is one filled with dark magic. With some artificing adjustments, it is capable of granting heightened strength and aggression to its wearer, but also makes them bloodthirsty and prone to careless zeal in battle.

table.name: Sea Spawn
rows: The blood of a sea spawn more resembles a dark brine than blood. Imbued with the magic that warped its original owner into a creature of the depths, this blood possesses a mutagenic effect that can grant humanoids some degree of amphibiousness when used correctly.

Sharp as a shark's and almost as numerous, the teeth of a sea spawn make nice collectibles when strung on necklaces and bracelets. Some coastal communities have taken to using them as fishing hooks in the belief that they increase the sizes of their catch.

entries: These quills possess the same poison found in a pufferfish, but with a higher yield appropriate for its upscaled owner. The quills maintain the poison for some time, making them useful as {@item dart|PHB|darts}.

entries.name: Use:
entries: You may use these quills as a {@item dart|PHB}. Any creature hit by this {@item dart|PHB} must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. Once a {@item dart|PHB} has {@condition poisoned} a creature in this way, it loses this property and becomes a normal {@item dart|PHB}.

rows: Extremely slimy and unpleasant to the touch, it is unfortunate that the tentacle loses much of its form and gripping strength after the demise of its owner. It does however have use as a waterproof rope, and it is not uncommon to find small wharfs in coastal communities lashed together with these tentacles.

table.name: Sea Spawn Trinket Table
rows: 1 {@item pouch|PHB} di fango di fondo oceanico (ottimo per le articolazioni doloranti e le maschere per il viso)
1 ricordo della vita precedente (foto, bambola, piccolo gioiello)

table.name: Shadow Mastiff
rows: Shadow mastiff drool drips like tar and is infused with the all-consuming darkness of the Shadowfell. While it may seem strange, Shadowfell inhabitants have been known to brew this drool into a hallucinogenic drink called "eclipse." When imbibed, eclipse causes the drinker to see "inverted light", making dark areas seem bright and bright areas seem dark. Frequent users of this drink can be identified by the telltale black circles with white outlines that stain their eyes and lips.

The fur of a shadow mastiff has an odd consistency, somehow combining attributes of a solid, liquid, and gas all at once. While it is a hard material to work with, its soft texture, and alluring movement make it a popular choice for making entertainingly macabre garments.

Too small to make a weapon, too uneven to make an arrowhead, a shadow mastiff's teeth are difficult to repurpose despite their useful ability to blend into the shadows. Thankfully, a crafty blacksmith realized that they could be made into a set of sneaky caltrops with only some slight modifications.

table.name: Slithering Tracker
rows: Although it greatly resembles water, the semi-liquid that constitutes a slithering tracker's form is a different substance entirely. Although it deteriorates rapidly once the tracker has been defeated, keeping it in an {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI} allows for the salvaging of some of its magic for a potion later on. {@b Requires {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI}.}

Even when they are defeated, a slithering tracker's lust for vengeance carries on. With a quick application of {@item spirit paper|HHHVI}, this gestalt field of emotion can be harvested and reused in a nefarious bit of magic. {@b Requires {@item spirit paper|HHHVI}.}

table.name: Spawn of Kyuss
rows: Gazing upon the brain of a spawn of Kyuss can upset even the most resilient of stomachs. Horribly blackened and rotten in undeath, it is either crawling with worms (which I would advise you kill immediately) or riddled with holes left by the aforementioned worms. While it is unquestionably disgusting, the brain is useful for crafting as it has been suffused with necrotic energies from its hellish parasites.

table.name: Tlincalli
rows: The sturdy legs of a tlincalli are just as capable of scrambling up sandy dunes as they are of marching across miles of baked earth. Once the tlincalli has died however, they can be quite easily snapped off at the joint and repurposed for a variety of tools.

The hard chitin of a tlincalli greatly resembles that of well-forged armor and it is not uncommon for desert-dwelling societies to proudly wear breastplates made from the tlincalli they fight. A less well known practice is turning the chitin into boards for surfing down sand dunes, taking advantage of the chitin's smooth and silica-phobic properties.

A tlincalli's tail greatly resembling that of an overgrown scorpion's. If steeped in saltwater, dried, oiled, then fitted with the proper mechanisms, this tail makes for a fine whip, capable of delivering large doses of poison.

entries: A naturally produced poison that the tlincalli use to even to coat their eggs. This poison is designed to debilitate rather than kill, lending itself well to the tlincalli's penchant for toying with those they hunt.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Can be used to coat up to 10 pieces of ammunition, or one slashing or piercing melee weapon. Applying this poison takes 1 minute. For the next minute, any creature successfully hit must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 4d6} poison damage on a failed save and becoming {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute, or half damage and no {@condition poisoned} condition on a successful save. If the target failed their saving throw by 5 or more the target is also {@condition paralyzed} while {@condition poisoned}. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

table.name: Trapper
rows: The hide of a trapper is known far and wide for its camouflage capabilities. Before it can be tanned, it must also be boiled in a weak solution of lime for a lengthy period of time in order to remove the trapper's remaining digestive acids. The effort is worth it however, as the end result is a fine material to craft a cloak coveted by thieves, spies, and assassins everywhere.

table.name: Vargouille
rows: The infamous curse of a vargouille is purely magical in nature and unfortunately cannot be traced back to any biological component for harvesting. That said, since their jaws act as the vector of the curse, they often become infused with trace elements of this Abyssal power and thus hold some utility for crafting fiendish (if ultimately harmless) items.

entries: Formed from the ears of the vargouille's original body, these wings are surprisingly powerful and seem to move independently on the vargouille's manic body. If sliced off quickly after the vargouille's defeat and then pinned with cold iron tacks, they maintain a semblance of magic that allows them to be reused elsewhere.

entries.name: Use:
entries: You may spend your action to pin these wings onto an easily pierceable object that weighs no more than 10 pounds. Once you do so, that object gains a low level of sentience that allows it to follow you around for 1 hour. The object has a fly speed of 10 feet and always attempts to take the most direct path to you, so long as you are within 60 feet of it. If you move farther than 60 feet away, or if there is an impassible object directly between you and the object, the object lands on the ground until you move within 60 feet again, or the path to you becomes clear. At the end of the hour, the wings on the object dissolve into a black ichor, and the object falls to the ground.

table.name: Vegepygmy
rows: Due to their bizarre origins, vegepygmy physiology can vary widely from specimen to specimen. While some may closely resemble humanoids with soft grey skin, others may appear more monstrous with twisted appendages and bulging green orbs for eyes. That said, there is one attribute that they all share, which is their frill. Its exact location on the vegepygmy's body can vary widely, but it is responsible for producing the vegepygmy's spores, as well as regulating air and moisture intake. By itself it is not worth much, but dried versions of it are used in some medical schools as a treatment for respiratory problems.

table.name: Vegepygmy Chief
rows: Due to their bizarre origins, vegepygmy physiology can vary widely from specimen to specimen. While some may closely resemble humanoids with soft grey skin, others may appear more monstrous with twisted appendages and bulging green orbs for eyes. That said, there is one attribute that they all share, which is their frill. Its exact location on the vegepygmy's body can vary widely, but it is responsible for producing the vegepygmy's spores, as well as regulating air and moisture intake. By itself it is not worth much, but dried versions of it are used in some medical schools as a treatment for respiratory problems.

entries: All vegepygmies grow out of a reddish brown spore called {@hazard russet mold|VGM}. As they grow older, their frills begin to produce this mold which accumulates around their body, waiting to be launched at unwary travelers.

entries.name: Use:
entries: This vial of spores is the equivalent of a square foot of {@hazard russet mold|VGM}. Refer to the {@hazard russet mold|VGM} tipbox in the vegepygmy's section to know more about {@hazard russet mold|VGM|russet mold's} effects.

table.name: Thorny
rows: Through some unknown system, {@hazard russet mold|VGM} is able to detect whether it is infesting a humanoid or a beast and mutate accordingly. As such, beasts spawn what are known as a "thorny". A marked difference between a thorny and a vegepygmy is its lack of a frill, instead growing scores of its eponymous thorns. While quite sharp, they lose their form quickly once its original owner has died. When mulched however, they make a fantastic fertilizer (but the resulting plants are known to be considerably more thorny than they would otherwise).

table.name: Wood Woad
rows: Much harder than regular bark and suffused with ancient nature magic, this bark makes a wonderful set of natural armor. To harvest, it is best advised to use a sharp knife to make vertical strips down the abdomen of the wood woad, to make splints for later.

The eyes of a wood woad are two sparkling motes of light and takes a particularly swift and practiced hand to extract and store before they dissipate. That said, they possess significant natural power, and have most likely seen more than most mortal creatures ever will. {@b Requires {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI}.}

entries: Despite common belief, the walnut-sized seed extracted from a wood woad is not the same seed that was implanted in its original heart, and thus cannot be used to spawn a new wood woad. Instead, this seed acts more like a focus for the wood woad, and is able to redistribute its energy into the forest after it has been destroyed. In a way, this can be seen as the wood woad's last act of dutiful service.

entries.name: Use:
entries: If this seed is planted at least 1 foot deep into loamy, fertile soil, it will sprout into a magical tree over the course of 1 year. When fully grown, this magical tree stands at 30 feet tall and greatly resembles a sturdy oak. This magical tree acts as a protector of any surrounding forest area. If a humanoid attempts to harm a tree within 2 miles of the magical tree, they must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or find themselves unable to willingly harm any living plant-life for 24 hours. In addition, plant-life that grows within 2 miles of the magical tree becomes noticeably stronger and grows at twice its normal rate.

table.name: Xvart
rows: Xvarts are pathetic creatures, possessing little talent or ability. Their one claim of power is their natural affinity for vermin (if one can even call that power) that lets them domesticate those beasts the way other humanoids domesticate cattle. This is helped in part by their tongues which can create the clicks and squeaks that mimic the calls of bats and rats. When taken, stripped, and dried, they can be used as a reed in the pipes of haunting.

table.name: Xvart Warlock of Raxivort
rows: Xvarts are pathetic creatures, possessing little talent or ability. Their one claim of power is their natural affinity for vermin (if one can even call that power) that lets them domesticate those beasts the way other humanoids domesticate cattle. This is helped in part by their tongues which can create the clicks and squeaks that mimic the calls of bats and rats. When taken, stripped, and dried, they can be used as a reed in the pipes of haunting.

On rare occasions, the craven demigod Raxivort musters enough courage to visit his accursed spawn and take what meagre offerings they have for him. On even rarer occasions, Raxivort will spare some of his power to a follower with the idea that they will bring him more offerings in the future. As befitting of his covetous nature, he brands his mark onto these followers which can then be taken and used for minor spellwork.

table.name: Yeth Hound
rows: Due to their nefarious creation, the power of the sun rejects yeth hounds, banishing them into the ethereal whenever it touches them. This property remains in their fur long even after their demise and can be reused as a component of particularly dark rituals.
The mocking bray of a yeth hound is matched by the calls of few other creatures. When a pack is hunting, these calls echo like a chorus, injecting fear into the unfortunate victim's mind.

A yeth hound's spine is surprisingly supple for such a large creature, and is not formed of vertebrae, but instead a single dark rod. When taken and oiled appropriately, it can be crafted into a bow that fires arrows that hunt down your enemies with the same relentlessness as the yeth hound itself.

table.name: Yuan-Ti Anathema
rows: The blood of a yuan-ti is strange in that it combines enzymes characteristic of both serpentine and humanoid physiology. This curious property allows unique opportunities in alchemy for the creation of the perfect antivenom for humanoids to consume.

entries: The venom of a yuan-ti combines elements of several of the most deadly snakes in nature. The poison has been described by survivors like "having one's blood transfigured into fire."

entries.name: Use:
entries: Can be used to coat up to 10 pieces of slashing or piercing ammunition or one slashing or piercing weapon. Applying the poison takes 1 minute. For the next minute, any creature successfully hit must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 2d6} poison damage on a failed save, or half that on a successful saving throw.

rows: A yuan-ti anathema constantly emits an aura of fear and loathing that cause creatures around it to flee. While this ability could easily be chalked up to any attribute of the anathema, magically speaking, it actually comes from its heart. Although this ability seems to cease once the heart stops beating, some mad tinkers have discovered ways to reanimate a heart long after its demise, thus allowing it to be repurposed as a useful magical trinket.

A yuan-ti spine is truly unique due to the number of branches it bares at the top to connect its many heads. Strong natural magic is required to support this twist of nature, and this magic can be invoked once the spine has been transformed into a magical staff.

table.name: Yuan-Ti Broodguard
rows: The blood of a yuan-ti is strange in that it combines enzymes characteristic of both serpentine and humanoid physiology. This curious property allows unique opportunities in alchemy for the creation of the perfect antivenom for humanoids to consume.

table.name: Yuan-Ti Mind Whisperer
rows: The blood of a yuan-ti is strange in that it combines enzymes characteristic of both serpentine and humanoid physiology. This curious property allows unique opportunities in alchemy for the creation of the perfect antivenom for humanoids to consume.

entries: The venom of a yuan-ti combines elements of several of the most deadly snakes in nature. The poison has been described by survivors like "having one's blood transfigured into fire."

entries.name: Use:
entries: Can be used to coat up to 10 pieces of slashing or piercing ammunition or one slashing or piercing weapon. Applying the poison takes 1 minute. For the next minute, any creature successfully hit must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 2d6} poison damage on a failed save, or half that on a successful saving throw.

Sseth, the Sibilant Death, is a particularly insidious god and was responsible for teaching the yuan-ti the "arts" of traps, poison, and murder. The mind whisperers that revere him are blessed with his mark (a flying snake with bared fangs) to grant them the cunning and wickedness to corrupt and conquer.

entries.name: Use:
entries: While wearing this mark, you may invoke its power as a free action to grant yourself advantage on your next Charisma ({@skill Deception}) or Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check. Once this ability has been used 5 times, this mark crumbles into dust and becomes worthless.

table.name: Yuan-Ti Nightmare Speaker
rows: The blood of a yuan-ti is strange in that it combines enzymes characteristic of both serpentine and humanoid physiology. This curious property allows unique opportunities in alchemy for the creation of the perfect antivenom for humanoids to consume.

entries: The venom of a yuan-ti combines elements of several of the most deadly snakes in nature. The poison has been described by survivors like "having one's blood transfigured into fire."

entries.name: Use:
entries: Can be used to coat up to 10 pieces of slashing or piercing ammunition or one slashing or piercing weapon. Applying the poison takes 1 minute. For the next minute, any creature successfully hit must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 2d6} poison damage on a failed save, or half that on a successful saving throw.

Dendar, the serpent goddess of nightmares, is revered by the aptly named nightmare speakers. She casts a pallor over sleeping mortals, inducing nightmares in them so that she may consume them in her never-ending hunger. Her most devout priestesses receive her mark so that they may call more nightmares into existence for her to devour.

entries.name: Use:
entries: You may use this mark in place of the usual material components when you cast the {@spell sleep} spell. If you do so, any creature that you successfully put to sleep in this way also suffers {@damage 1d10} psychic damage at the end of every turn they spend asleep. This damage does not wake up the sleeping creature. Once this ability has been used 3 times, this mark crumbles into dust and becomes worthless.

table.name: Yuan-Ti Pit Master
rows: The blood of a yuan-ti is strange in that it combines enzymes characteristic of both serpentine and humanoid physiology. This curious property allows unique opportunities in alchemy for the creation of the perfect antivenom for humanoids to consume.

entries: The venom of a yuan-ti combines elements of several of the most deadly snakes in nature. The poison has been described by survivors like "having one's blood transfigured into fire."

entries.name: Use:
entries: Can be used to coat up to 10 pieces of slashing or piercing ammunition or one slashing or piercing weapon. Applying the poison takes 1 minute. For the next minute, any creature successfully hit must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 2d6} poison damage on a failed save, or half that on a successful saving throw.

Merrshaulk, the Master of the Pit, was once the prime deity of the yuan-ti pantheon before he was unseated in some unknown event. He slumbers now, but still lends his mark (a cobra head) to his most devout followers: the stoic pit masters. With his blessing, they maintain the traditions of the yuan-ti, whether that be through diplomacy or by force.

entries.name: Use:
entries: While holding this mark, if you are forced to roll a saving throw to resist being {@condition charmed} or put to sleep, you may invoke the power of this mark to automatically succeed on that saving throw. Once this ability has been used 5 times, this mark crumbles into dust and becomes worthless.

baseitem.name: Bone Plate Armor
entries: {@b Bone} plate consists of shaped, interlocking {@b bone} plates to cover the entire body. A suit of bone plate includes gauntlets, heavy leather boots, a visored helmet, and thick layers of padding underneath the armor. Buckles and straps distribute the weight over the body.

item.name: Amulet of Dragonkin
entries: This amulet is the same color as the {@creature guard drake|MPMM} from whom it was crafted. While wearing this amulet, your appearance takes on a more dragon-like aesthetic. You grow patches of scales over your body (the same color as the amulet), your eyes become lizard-like, your teeth grow sharper and you grow a foot-long, prehensile tail from your back. You gain no other benefits from this amulet, however. All these attributes disappear instantly if the amulet is removed.

item.name: Amulet of Enslavement
entries: While you are wearing this amulet, any {@condition charmed|PHB|charm} effect that currently afflicts you is considered to have an infinite duration instead of its usual duration. Once this amulet has been worn for a cumulative total of 24 hours, it crumbles into dust and becomes worthless.

item.name: Amulet of Imix
entries: While wearing and attuned to this amulet, you gain 5 temporary hit points whenever you reduce an enemy to 0 hit points. In addition, any time you are forced to roll a Constitution saving throw to maintain control of a fire elemental or maintain {@condition concentration} on a spell that deals fire damage, you do so at advantage.

item.name: Amulet of Telepathic Control
entries: While wearing this amulet, you gain the following abilities:

items: You have telepathy out to a range of 1 mile You are aware of the presence of creatures within 100 feet of you that have an Intelligence score of 4 or higher.
You know the distance and direction to those creatures but can't sense anything else about them.
You may cast the {@spell dominate monster} spell without requiring any components or using any spell slots. Once this ability has been used once, it cannot be used again until the next dawn.

item.name: Amulet of the Closed Heart
entries: While wearing this amulet, you are immune to magic that allows other creatures to read your thoughts, determine whether you are lying, know your alignment, or know your creature type. Creatures can telepathically communicate with you only if you allow it.

In addition, you gain the ability to spend your action to create a pulse of emotionally dampening mental energy in a 30-foot radius around yourself. Any creature in that radius that is under a {@condition charmed|PHB|charm} or {@condition frightened|PHB|fear} condition that would end on a successful saving throw may immediately attempt that saving throw, adding your Intelligence modifier in addition to their normal modifiers.

item.name: Amulet of the Forest
entries: This green amulet possesses two sparkling motes of light inside of it. While wearing this amulet, you may spend 1 minute focusing on a living tree within 5 feet of you. If you do so, you gain an innate bond with that tree that lasts for the next 24 hours. This bond grants the tree a low level of sentience, similar to the {@spell speak with plants} spell, with the additional bonus that you and the tree may communicate over any distance so long as you are both on the same plane of existence. You may also spend your action to experience what the tree is experiencing until the start of your next turn, during which you are {@condition deafened|PHB|deaf} and {@condition blinded|PHB|blind} regarding your own senses.
